pageData.text: Acid-base, fluid, and electrolyte balances must be maintained in order to maintain the dynamically stable internal state of the body known as homeostasis. The acidity level (often expressed as pH) of all organisms is highly regulated. A slight increase or decrease in acidity can have a detrimental effect on the well-being of an individual. Enzymes in the body have an optimum pH at which they work at peak efficiency. Any changes in the pH of body fluids will disrupt the balance of dissolved elements and make these enzymes less efficient.

pageData.text: Donald and Winston are identical twins, and college roommates, with varying interests. Donald enjoys being active, while Winston prefers to play guitar in a local band. The brothers are also enrolled in the same science course where they are learning about pH and homeostasis in the human body. One Saturday afternoon, Donald plays in a basketball tournament while Winston writes songs at a coffee shop. When they return home that night, they decide to conduct a quick experiment. Using pH test strips, they test the pH of their urine to see how their levels of physical activity affected their body pH. What would be the pH difference between the two samples and why?

Donald would have a lower, or more <button class='glossary-text'>acidic</button>, pH than Winston. This is due to the removal of lactic acid from Donald’s body after his tournament. Lactic acid is produced by muscle cells when oxygen levels are low, like during prolonged exercise. This process is very similar to the yeast fermentation involved in the preparation of sauerkraut and pickles. When cells produce lactic acid, it is removed from the blood by the kidneys and expelled during urination.

pageData.desc: Several men in wheelchairs in athletic uniforms on a basketball court with spectators in the bleachers.
pageData.altText: Several men in wheelchairs in athletic uniforms on a basketball court with spectators in the bleachers.

pageData.text: Water is composed of one atom of oxygen and two atoms of hydrogen. Even in pure water, not every oxygen and hydrogen atom is bound to each other. Water molecules constantly dissociate into H+ and OH– ions, which then come back together to re-form water molecules. A balance exists between free atoms and atoms that are bound to each other, although a molecule of water can easily lose a hydrogen atom. It should be noted that these free hydrogen ions (H+) do not actually exist as such in an aqueous solution. Rather, the hydrogen ions will associate with adjacent oxygen atoms to form . However, for the sake of convenience in our discussion of pH and , we will refer to these ions as “H+,” rather than “H3O+.” Free hydrogen ions have a positive charge, while the molecule remaining (OH- ) is called a , which has a negative charge. This balance of ion exchange in water can be seen as follows:

pageData.altText: Chemical equation for the reaction in which water molecules dissociate into hydrogen and hydroxide ions, which recombine to form water.

pageData.text: Because the hydrogen ion has a positive charge, it is an electron acceptor and will try to bind to any negatively-charged particle. In contrast, the hydroxide ion is negatively-charged and will try to react with any positively-charged particle. In a situation where there are the same amounts of hydrogen and hydroxide ions, the water is considered . In a situation where there are more hydrogen ions than hydroxide ions, the solution is , while a solution with more hydroxide ions is called basic or .

In neutral water, the concentrations of hydrogen and hydroxide ions are equal, although the actual numbers of hydrogen and hydroxide ions are very small. Under these conditions, for every molecule of water, there are only 0.0000001 free ions of H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup> and OH<sup class='bodySupscript'>-</sup> present. In other words, you will have one free hydrogen ion and one free hydroxide ion for every 10,000,000 molecules of water. The term “[H<sup class='bodySupscript'>+</sup>]” signifies the concentration of hydrogen ions present in the solution. The concentration of hydrogen ions in a neutral solution can be written as follows:
[H+] = 1 x 10-7 moles/liter

To make the acidity or alkalinity of a solution easier to express, an annotated method was developed. In this method, one takes the logarithm of the concentration shown in bold above. Keep in mind that [H+] only equals 1 x 10-7 mol/liter in a completely solution. Thus, the resulting number from the example above is 7, which is written as pH 7. The “7” comes directly from the exponent of the hydrogen ion concentration expressed in scientific notation. Note that the exponent is negative, while the pH is positive. Now, consider a solution that is less (or more basic) with a pH of 8. This pH value indicates the concentration of hydrogen ions in this solution is [H+] = 1 x 10-8 mol/liter, or ten times less concentrated than that of a neutral solution. Thus, a solution with a higher pH actually has fewer hydrogen ions than a solution with a lower pH.

A logarithm is a mathematical function in which the exponent (the superscript number) indicates how many times the base number is multiplied or divided by itself. If the exponent is positive, the base number is multiplied by itself. For example, 102 would be written as: 10 x 10 =100. However, when the exponent is negative, the base number is divided by itself: 10-2 would be written as 1/10 x 10 or 1/100 = 0.02.

A solution with the highest possible concentration of hydrogen ions has a pH of 0 (pure acid), while a solution with the lowest possible concentration of hydrogen ions has a pH of 14 (pure base or ). As a result, a solution’s pH is between 0 and 14 and can be used to easily express how acidic or basic the solution is. A higher concentration of hydrogen ions results in a lower concentration of and vice versa. This relationship is called the .

This relationship between hydrogen and <button class='glossary-text'>hydroxide ions</button> can be depicted on a pH scale (Figure 1), which shows the pH of some common foods, household items, and body fluids.

In Figure 1, we see that blood is not completely <button class='glossary-text'>neutral</button>; it has a pH between 7.35 and 7.45. If the pH value of blood drops below pH 7.35, the body will go into a state of <button class='glossary-text'>acidosis</button>; a blood pH that is too high results in <button class='glossary-text'>alkalosis</button>. Both conditions can lead to significant health problems because the human body requires a very narrow pH range to function properly. Consumption of food, breathing, or even drinking water causes slight changes in the blood’s pH. To prevent a pH imbalance, certain molecules, called <button class='glossary-text'>buffers</button>, can prevent the pH from becoming too low or too high. Under <button class='glossary-text'>acidic</button> conditions, buffers behave more like basic substances, but under <button class='glossary-text'>alkaline</button> conditions, they behave more like acids. Their presence helps maintain the pH balance of the body, which is part of homeostasis.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: The pH scale which ranges from 0-14, with 0 being the most acidic, and 14 the most alkaline.

pageData.question: What condition results if an individual’s blood pH is too low?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: If the pH value of blood drops below pH 7.35, the body will go into a state of acidosis.

pageData.question: What is the lowest value of the normal pH range for blood?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: Blood is not completely neutral; it has a narrow pH range between 7.35 and 7.45.

hintData.title: Hint

If the pH value of blood drops below the normal range, the body will go into a state of acidosis; a blood pH that is too high results in alkalosis. Both conditions can lead to significant health problems because the human body requires a very narrow pH range to function properly. Consumption of food, breathing, or even drinking water causes slight changes in the blood’s pH.

pageData.text: There are two main types of systems. consist of chemical compounds that bind hydrogen ions when pH falls and release hydrogen ions when pH rises. consist of activities such as breathing and urine production that adjust the of the body.

In this investigation, you will measure the pH of common household items and determine the effectiveness of a phosphate buffer in maintaining the pH balance of a solution. In another part of the experiment, you will explore the effect of respiration on pH.

The <button class='glossary-text'>phosphate buffer system</button> is a chemical buffer system that is particularly important in the urinary system and intracellular fluid. It is very similar to that of the <button class='glossary-text'>bicarbonate buffer system</button>. It involves sodium dihydrogen phosphate (NaH<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>PO<sub class='bodySubscript'>4</sub>), a weak acid, and sodium monohydrogen phosphate (Na<sup class='bodySupscript'>2</sup>HPO<sub class='bodySubscript'>4</sub>), a weak base. When the weak base encounters a strong acid, such as hydrochloric acid (HCl), it binds to a hydrogen ion, forming the weak acid and sodium chloride (NaCl). When the weak acid encounters a strong base, such as sodium hydroxide (NaOH), it releases a hydrogen ion, forming the weak base and water.

pageData.altText: Equations Showing the components of the phosphate buffer system encountering a strong acid and a strong base.

pageData.text: The bicarbonate buffer system is important for protecting the pH of extracellular as well as intracellular fluid. It involves carbonic acid (H2CO3), a weak acid, and sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3), a weak base. When sodium bicarbonate encounters a strong acid, it binds to a free hydrogen ion to form the weak acid and sodium chloride (NaCl). When carbonic acid encounters a strong base, it releases a hydrogen ion, forming the weak base and water.

pageData.altText: Equations Showing the actions of the bicarbonate buffer system encountering a strong acid and a strong base.

pageData.question: The phosphate buffer system is a chemical buffer system that is particularly important in ______ and intracellular fluid.

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The phosphate buffer system is a chemical buffer system that is particularly important in the urinary system and intracellular fluid.

pageData.question: In a chemical buffer system, what happens when the weak acid encounters a strong base?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: When the weak acid of a chemical buffer system encounters a strong base, it releases a hydrogen ion, forming the weak base and water. This lowers the pH of the solution and mitigates the alkaline effects of the strong base.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The phosphate buffer system is very important in the urinary system and intracellular fluid. It involves sodium dihydrogen phosphate (NaH<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>PO<sub class='bodySubscript'>4</sub>), a weak acid, and sodium monohydrogen phosphate (Na<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>HPO<sub class='bodySubscript'>4</sub>), a weak base. When the weak base encounters a strong acid, such as hydrochloric acid (HCl), it binds to a hydrogen ion, forming the weak acid and sodium chloride (NaCl). When the weak acid encounters a strong base, such as sodium hydroxide (NaOH), it releases a hydrogen ion, forming the weak base and water.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: The phosphate buffer system is very important in the urinary system and intracellular fluid. It involves sodium dihydrogen phosphate (NaH<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>PO<sub class='bodySubscript'>4</sub>), a weak acid, and sodium monohydrogen phosphate (Na<sub class='bodySubscript'>2</sub>HPO<sub class='bodySubscript'>4</sub>), a weak base. When the weak base encounters a strong acid, such as hydrochloric acid (HCl), it binds to a hydrogen ion, forming the weak acid and sodium chloride (NaCl). When the weak acid encounters a strong base, such as sodium hydroxide (NaOH), it releases a hydrogen ion, forming the weak base and water.

pageData.text: The is a powerful for the blood. Cellular respiration continuously generates carbon dioxide (CO2). Carbon dioxide combines with water, the solvent for blood and other body fluids, to form carbonic acid (H2CO3), part of the . The carbonic acid dissociates into hydrogen and bicarbonate (HCO3-) ions. The double arrows in Figure 2 indicate a reversible equilibrium, meaning that the reaction can shift directions as needed if pH starts to rise or fall. Normally, the bicarbonate buffer system helps keep blood pH in check while carbon dioxide is continuously eliminated from the body. This is accomplished by breathing. When gas exchange occurs in the lungs, the blood takes up inhaled oxygen, which is needed for cellular respiration, and releases carbon dioxide, which is then exhaled. The respiratory center of the brain is sensitive to the carbon dioxide content and pH of the blood. Too much carbon dioxide, and the respiratory center triggers an increase in the rate and depth of breathing to rid the body of this gas and raise the pH of the blood. If blood pH becomes too , the respiratory center reduces the rate and depth of breathing, allowing carbon dioxide to accumulate in the blood.

pageData.altText: Chemical equation showing the reversible equilibrium between carbon dioxide and water, carbonic acid, and bicarbonate ion.
Figure 2: Movement of carbon dioxide through tissues and blood cells involves several equilibrium reactions.

pageData.text:
CNX_Chem_13_00_Blood.png by CNX is available under CC BY 4.0 at

pageData.question: The bicarbonate buffer system relies on which process to help keep the pH of blood in the correct range?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: The bicarbonate buffer system helps keep blood pH in check while carbon dioxide is continuously eliminated from the body through the process of breathing.

pageData.question: What happens if blood pH becomes too alkaline?

feedbackData.title: Feedback
feedbackData.text: If blood pH becomes too alkaline, the respiratory center reduces the rate and depth of breathing, allowing carbon dioxide to accumulate in the blood.

hintData.title: Hint
hintData.body: Normally, the bicarbonate buffer system helps keep blood pH in check while carbon dioxide is continuously eliminated from the body. When gas exchange occurs in the lungs, the blood takes up inhaled oxygen, which is needed for cellular respiration, and releases carbon dioxide, which is then exhaled. The respiratory center of the brain is sensitive to the carbon dioxide content and pH of the blood. Too much carbon dioxide, and the respiratory center triggers an increase in the rate and depth of breathing to rid the body of this gas and raise the pH of the blood. If blood pH becomes too alkaline, the respiratory center reduces the rate and depth of breathing, allowing carbon dioxide to accumulate in the blood.

pageData.desc: This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, you will test the pH of at least seven common household liquids using pH test strips. In Activity 2, you will measure the changes in pH of distilled water as a strong acid and a strong base are added dropwise. In Activity 3, you will measure the changes in pH of a buffer solution as a strong acid and a strong base are added dropwise. In Activity 4, you will observe the change in pH as carbon dioxide is respirated into a sample of distilled water.

In Activity 4, you will observe the change in pH as carbon dioxide is respirated into a sample of distilled water.

pageData.text: Reorder Information: Replacement supplies for the pH and Homeostasis investigation can be ordered from Carolina Biological Supply Company, item number 580550. Call: 866-332-4478 to order.

Read all instructions for this laboratory activity before beginning any procedures. Follow the instructions closely and observe established laboratory safety practices, including the use of appropriate Personal Protective Equipment (PPE) described in the Safety and Procedures sections. Always wear an apron, gloves and safety goggles while handling any of the chemicals in this investigation.

pageData.subTitle: Personal protective equipment (PPE)
pageData.altText: goggles symbol, gloves symbol, apron symbol

pageData.text: Do not eat, drink, or chew gum while performing these activities. Wash your hands with soap and water before and after performing the activities. Clean up the work space with soap and water after completing the investigation. Keep pets and children away from lab materials and equipment.

Strong acids and bases can be dangerous to your health. This investigation comes with 1 M hydrochloric acid (HCl), and 1 M sodium hydroxide (NaOH), which is a base. Even acids and bases that are approved for household use may cause severe damage to the skin and/or eyes. Thus, PPE should be worn while performing the activities in this investigation. In case of contact with eyes, rinse immediately with copious amounts of water and seek medical attention. In case of contact with skin or clothing, remove contaminated clothing and rinse the skin thoroughly with water for at least 10 minutes.
Never mix acids and bases, as this can lead to potentially dangerous chemical reactions that are harmful to human health.
pageData.altText: corrosion symbol, warning symbol

pageData.title: Pre-Lab Assessment Introduction
pageData.text: Directions: Complete this pre-lab assessment to continue to the rest of the investigation. You will need a score of 100% to pass the assessment. This assessment can be attempted as many times as necessary to achieve a passing score. You may return to the pre-lab sections to study before each attempt.<span class='bodyParaLineBreak'>For each question, select your response and then click Submit to see how you did. Click Next to continue to the next question. A final results page will appear upon completion of this assessment with your overall performance.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the composition of pure water with a pH of 7?

options.text: The concentrations of hydrogen ions and hydroxide ions are equal.
There are more hydrogen ions than hydroxide ions.
There are more hydroxide ions than hydrogen ions.
There are no hydroxide ions, only hydrogen ions.
There are no hydroxide ions, only hydronium ions.

assestmentData.question: If the concentration of hydrogen ions in a solution is 1 x 10-9 moles/liter, what is the pH of the solution?

A flask contains water and buffer and has a pH of 6. Several drops of strong acid are added to the flask; however, the pH remains at about 6. Which of the following best explains the role of the buffer in this phenomenon?

options.text: Buffers can respond to pH changes by accepting or releasing hydrogen ions.
Buffers can respond to pH changes by transforming hydrogen ions into hydroxide ions.
Buffers can respond to pH changes by lowering the solution’s activation energy.
Buffers can respond to pH changes by modifying their 3D structure.
Buffers can respond to pH changes by charging nearby particles.

assestmentData.question: Carbon dioxide dissolved in blood creates carbonic acid and causes blood to become acidic. To prevent blood from becoming too acidic, which of the following processes continuously removes excess carbon dioxide from the bloodstream?

options.text: adding bicarbonate ions from the lungs
adding insulin produced by the pancreas

assestmentData.question: Which of the following best describes the 1 M sodium hydroxide provided in your lab kit for this investigation?

options.text: It is volatile and releases fumes.

assestmentData.question: At least seven different household liquids are needed for this investigation but are not supplied in your lab kit. Which of the following is an inappropriate household liquid to use in the investigation for safety reasons?

The phosphate buffer system involves sodium dihydrogen phosphate (NaH2PO4), a weak acid, and sodium monohydrogen phosphate (Na2HPO4), a weak base. Which of the following describes how this buffer system responds to the presence of a strong base?

options.text: The weak acid releases a hydrogen ion, forming the weak base and water.
The weak base releases a hydrogen ion, forming the weak acid and hydronium.
The weak acid releases a hydroxide ion, forming the weak base and a strong acid.
The weak base releases a hydroxide ion, forming the weak acid and water.
The weak acid releases water, forming a strong base and a phosphate group.

assestmentData.question: Which of the following will be used to measure the pH of the solutions in Activities 1-3 of this investigation?

Clean and sanitize the work area.
Read the instructions carefully.
Obtain all necessary materials.
In Activity 1, you will test the pH of at least seven common household liquids using pH test strips.

pages.title: Titration of Vinegar with Sodium Hydroxide (18 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Measuring the pH of Common Household Items (6 steps)

pageData.text: Fill a foam cup about one-quarter full with a common household liquid of your choice.
Dip a pH indicator strip into the liquid.
Remove the strip; while it is still wet, compare the color of the test strip with the reference color chart and take a photo to document your observation.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Pour the solution down a sink drain. Flush the sink thoroughly with water for at least 30 seconds.
Repeat this procedure with the next solution in a new cup. Continue until you have recorded the pH of at least seven different substances in Data Table 1, and have taken a photo of each strip.

One at a time, empty the contents of each cup down a sink drain with the tap water running. Allow the tap water to run at least 30 seconds between each cup to avoid mixing acids and bases. Let the water run for at least 30 seconds after the last cup has been emptied before turning off the faucet. Rinse the cups with tap water before discarding them in household trash; do not reuse them.
In Activity 2, you will measure the changes in pH of distilled water as a strong acid and a strong base are added dropwise.

pages.title: Titration of Vinegar with Sodium Hydroxide (18 steps)
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Changes in pH After Addition of Acidic and Alkaline Solutions (7 steps)

pageData.text: Label one test tube “acid” and a second tube “alkaline.” Fill both test tubes about half-full with distilled water.

typeBefore.text: Note: Activities 2 and 3 may be set up and carried out separately as written, or at the same time if desired. They are identical except for the use of a phosphate in Activity 3. If doing both activities simultaneously, be sure that test tubes containing water or phosphate buffer are clearly labeled as such in addition to being labeled as “acid” or “.”

pageData.text: Measure the pH of the distilled water in each tube by dipping a separate pH indicator strip into the water in each of the tubes. You will need to tilt the tubes gently to wet the pH strips as shown in the following video: pH in a Test Tube. Record these pH values in Data Table 2, and take a picture of each pH strip while it is still wet.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Add 1 drop of 1 M hydrochloric acid (HCl), an solution, to the tube labeled “acid.”
Add 1 drop of 1 M sodium hydroxide (NaOH), a basic or alkaline solution, to the tube labeled “alkaline.”
Using new indicator strips, measure the pH of the solution in each tube as described in Step 2. Record the pH of the solutions in Data Table 2.
Repeat steps 3–5 13 more times and record the pH values in Data Table 2. At the end, take a picture of the pH strips used for the final measurements of both tubes.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Empty the tubes down a sink drain with the tap water running. Allow the water to run at least 30 seconds after emptying the “acidic” tubes before emptying the “alkaline” tubes. Let the water run for at least 30 seconds after the last tube before turning off the tap. Rinse all tubes thoroughly with water and allow them to air-dry.
In Activity 3, you will measure the changes in pH of a <button class='glossary-text'>buffer</button> solution as a strong acid and a strong base are added dropwise.

pages.title: Changes in pH and the Effectiveness of a Phosphate Buffer
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Changes in pH and the Effectiveness of a Phosphate Buffer (7 steps)

pageData.text: Label one clean, dry test tube “acid” and a second “.” Fill both test tubes about half-full with sodium phosphate solution.

Measure the pH of the buffer solution in each tube using pH indicator strips as described in Activity 2. Record these pH values in Data Table 2, and take a picture of each pH strip while it is still wet.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Add 1 drop of 1 M hydrochloric acid (HCl) to the tube labeled “acid.”
Add 1 drop of 1 M sodium hydroxide (NaOH),to the tube labeled “alkaline.”
Using new indicator strips, measure the pH of the solution in each tube. Record the pH of the solutions in Data Table 3.
Repeat steps 3–5 13 more times and record the pH values in Data Table 3. At the end, take a picture of the pH strips used for the final measurements of both tubes.
pageData.altText: camera symbol

pageData.text: Empty the tubes down a sink drain with the tap water running. Allow the water to run at least 30 seconds after emptying the “” tubes before emptying the “alkaline” tubes. Let the water run for at least 30 seconds after the last tube before turning off the tap. Rinse all tubes thoroughly with water and set them aside to air-dry.
In Activity 4, you will observe the change in pH as carbon dioxide is respirated into a sample of distilled water.

pages.title: Effect of Carbon Dioxide from Exhalation on pH
pages.pageTitle:
A
 Effect of Carbon Dioxide from Exhalation on pH (1 step)

pageData.text: View the following video: Breathing and Homeostasis

typeBefore.text: Note: In this activity, you will observe an alternative way of monitoring changes in pH. Instead of dipping pH strips into a liquid, a universal indicator solution is added. If the pH of the liquid shifts, its color will change. The color is compared to a pH chart for interpretation. In the video below, the chart has 7 color squares corresponding to pH values between 4 and 10. The chart is read left to right, with each square representing 1 pH unit.

pageData.text: As you watch, record the changes in pH that are demonstrated in Data Table 4.

text: Clean all surfaces with soap and water.
Dispose of all waste (foam cups, paper towels, used pH strips, etc.) in household trash.
Clean, dry test tubes may be returned to your lab kit.

text: What happened to the pH of the water and the sodium phosphate buffer solution after five minutes of exhalation? Were the results different, and if so, why? Use your knowledge of buffer systems in the answer.

pageData.altText: Figure 1: The pH scale which ranges from 0-14, with 0 being the most acidic, and 14 the most alkaline.
Figure 2: Movement of carbon dioxide through tissues and blood cells involves several equilibrium reactions.

This map describes the procedural workflow for this investigation. In Activity 1, you will test the pH of at least seven common household liquids using pH test strips. In Activity 2, you will measure the changes in pH of distilled water as a strong acid and a strong base are added dropwise. In Activity 3, you will measure the changes in pH of a buffer solution as a strong acid and a strong base are added dropwise. In Activity 4, you will observe the change in pH as carbon dioxide is respirated into a sample of distilled water.

data.title: Acid-base balance
data.content: A higher concentration of hydrogen ions results in a lower concentration of hydroxide ions and vice versa

data.title: Acidic
data.content: Where there are more hydrogen ions than hydroxide ions

data.title: Acidosis
data.content: A condition in which the blood's pH is too acidic

data.title: Alkaline (basic)
data.content: A solution with more hydroxide ions than hydrogen ions

data.title: Alkalosis
data.content: A condition in which the blood's pH is too alkaline

data.title: Bicarbonate buffer system
data.content: Protects the pH of extracellular as well as intracellular fluid, when sodium bicarbonate encounters a strong acid, it binds to a free hydrogen ion to form the weak acid and sodium chloride (NaCl), when carbonic acid encounters a strong base, it releases a hydrogen ion, forming the weak base and water

data.title: Buffer
data.content: Prevent the pH from becoming too low or too high

data.title: Chemical buffer systems
data.content: Consist of chemical compounds that bind hydrogen ions when pH falls and release hydrogen ions when pH rises

data.title: Hydroxide ion
data.content: One oxygen bonded to one hydrogen, negatively charged

data.title: Neutral
data.content: There are the same amounts of hydrogen and hydroxide ions

data.title: Phosphate buffer system
data.content: A chemical buffer system that is particularly important in the urinary system and intracellular fluid

data.title: Physiological buffers systems
data.content: Activities such as breathing and urine production that adjust the acid-base balance of the body

data.title: Respiratory system
data.content: A powerful physiological buffer system for the blood
